editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE MALE-COQUETTE: OR, Seventeen Hundred Fifty-Seven.
THE MALE-COQUETTE: OR, Seventeen Hundred Fifty-Seven.
As it is Performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL In DRURY-LANE.
LONDON: Printed for P. VAILLANT, facing Southampton-Street, in the Strand. MDCCLVII.

THE following Scenes were written with no other View than to ſerve Mr. Woodward laſt Year at his Benefit; and to expoſe a Set of People, (the Daffodils) whom the Author thinks more prejudicial to the Community, than the various Characters of Bucks, Bloods, Flaſhes and Fribbles, which have by Turns infeſted the Town, and been juſtly ridicul'd upon the Stage. He expects no Mercy from the Critics: But the more indulgent Public, perhaps, will excuſe his Endeavours to pleaſe them, when they ſhall know, that the Performance was plan'd, written, and acted in leſs than a Month.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.byline: WRITTEN AND SPOKEN By Mr. GARRICK.

lg.l: WHY to this Farce this Title given,
Of Seventeen Hundred Fifty Seven?
Is it a Regiſter of Faſhions,
Of Follies, Frailties, fav'rite Paſſions?
Or is't deſign'd to make appear,
How happy, good, and wiſe you were,
In this ſame memorable Year?
Sure with our Author Wit was ſcarce,
To croud ſo many Virtues in a Farce.
Perhaps 'tis meant to make you ſtare,
Like Cloths hung out at Country Fair;
On which ſtrange Monſters glare and grin,
To draw the gaping Bumpkins in.—
Tho' 'tis the Genius of the Age,
To catch the Eye with Title-Page;
Yet here we dare not ſo abuſe ye—
We have ſome Monſters to amuſe ye.
Ye Slaves to Faſhion, Dupes of Chance;
Whom Fortune leads her fickle Dance:
Who, as the Dice ſhall ſmile or frown,
Are rich and poor, and up and down;
Whoſe Minds eternal Vigils keep;
Who—like Macbeth, have murder'd Sleep!—
Each modiſh Vice this Night ſhall riſe,
Like Banquo's Ghoſt, before your Eyes;
While, conſcious you, ſhall ſtart and roar—
Hence, horrid Farce!—we'll ſee no more!—
—Ye Ladies, too—Maids, Widows, Wives—
Now tremble for your naughty Lives!
How will your Hearts go pit-a-pat?—
Bleſs me!—Lord!—what's the Fellow at?—
Was Poet e'er ſo rude before?
Why ſure the Brute will ſay no more—
Again!—O Gad!—I cannot bear—
Here—you Boxkeeper,—call my Chair:
Peace, Ladies—'tis a falſe Alarm—
To YOU our Author means no Harm.
His Female Failings all are Fictions:
To which your Lives are Contradictions.
Th' unnatural Fool has drawn a Plan,
Where Women like a worthleſs Man,
A Fault ne'er heard of ſince the World began.
This Year he lets you ſteal away—
But if the next you trip or ſtray;
His Muſe, he vows, on you ſhall wait,
In Seventeen Hundred Fifty-eight.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: Enter ARABELLA, and SOPHIA in Men's Cloaths.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: INDEED, my Dear, you'll repent this Frolic.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Indeed, my Dear, then it will be the firſt Frolic I ever repented in all my Life. Lookee, Bell, 'tis in vain to oppoſe me, for I am reſolv'd—the only Way to find out his Character, is to ſee him thus, and converſe freely with him. If he is the Wretch he is reported to be, I ſhall away with him at once; and if he is not, he will thank me for the Trial, and our Union will be the ſtronger.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: I never knew a Woman yet, who had Prudence enough to turn off a pretty Fellow, becauſe he had a little more Wickedneſs than the reſt of his Neighbours.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Then I will be the firſt to ſet a better Example. —If I did not think a Man's Character was of ſome Conſequence, I ſhould not now run ſuch Riſques, and encounter ſuch Difficulties, to be better acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Ha, Sophy! if you have Love enough to be jealous, and Jealouſy enough to try theſe Experiments —don't imagine, tho' you ſhould make terrible Diſcoveries, that you can immediately quit your Inclinations, with your Breeches; and return ſo very philoſophically to your Petticoats again, ha, ha!—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: You may be as merry with my Weakneſſes, as you pleaſe, Madam; but I know my own Heart, and can rely upon it.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: We are great Bullies by Nature; but Courage and Swaggering, are two Things, Couſin.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Since you are as little to be convinc'd, as I am to be perſuaded—your Servant—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Nay, Sophy—This is unfriendly—if you are reſolv'd upon your Scheme, open to me without Reſerve, and I'll aſſiſt you.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Imprimis, then; I confeſs to you, that I have a kind of whimſical Attachment to Daffodil; not but I can ſee his Vanities, and laugh at 'em.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: And like him the better for 'em—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Pſhaw! don't plague me, Bell—my other Lover, the jealous Mr. Tukely—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Who loves you too well to be ſucceſsful—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: And whom I really eſteem—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: As a good Sort of Man, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Nay, ſhou'd have lov'd him—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Had not a prettier Fellow ſtept in between, who perhaps does not care a Farthing for you—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: That's the Queſtion, my Dear—Tukely, I ſay, either ſtung by Jealouſy, or unwilling to loſe me, without a Struggle, has intreated me to know more of his Rival, before I engage too far with him— Many ſtrange Things he has told me, which have piqu'd me I muſt confeſs, and I am now prepar'd for the Proof.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: You'll certainly be diſcover'd, and put to Shame.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I have ſecur'd my Succeſs already.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I have ſeen him, convers'd with him, and am to meet him again to-day, by his own Appointment.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Madneſs!—it can't be.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: But it has been, I tell you—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: How? how?—Quickly, quickly, dear Sophy?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: When you went to Lady Fanny's laſt Night, and left me, as you thought, little diſpos'd for a Frolic, I dreſs'd me as you ſee, call'd a Chair, and went to the King's-Arms—ask'd for my Gentleman, and was ſhewn into a Room—he immediately left his Company, and came to me.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: I tremble for you.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I introduc'd myſelf as an Italian Nobleman, juſt arriv'd: Il Marcheſe di Macaroni—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Ridiculous!—ha, ha.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: An Intimate of Sir Charles Vainlove's, who is now at Rome—I told him my Letters were with my Baggage, at the Cuſtom-houſe—He receiv'd me with all the Openneſs imaginable, and wou'd have introduc'd me to his Friends; I begg'd to be excus'd, but promis'd to attend him to-day, and am now ready, as you ſee, to keep my Word.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing!—and what did you talk about?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p:
Of various Things—Women among the reſt; and tho' I have not abſolutely any open Acts of Rebellion againſt him, yet, I fear he is a Traytor at Heart —and then ſuch Vanity!—but I had not Time
to make great Diſcoveries—It was merely the Prologue— The Play is to come.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Act your Part well, or we ſhall hiſs you—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Never fear me; you don't know what a mad, raking, wild young Devil I can be, if I ſet my Mind to it, Bell.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: You fright me!—you ſhall poſitively be no Bedfellow of mine any longer.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I am reſolv'd to ruin my Woman, and kill my Man, before I get into Petticoats again.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Take Care of a Quarrel tho'—a Rival may be too rough with you.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
ARABELLA.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh! Mr. Tukely is here—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Now for a Trial of Skill; if I deceive him, you'll allow that half my Buſineſs is done.
sp.stage: [She walks aſide, takes out a Glaſs, and looks at the Pictures.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Your Servant Miſs Bell—I need not ask if Miſs Sophy be at home, for I believe I have ſeen her ſince you did.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Have you, Sir? You ſeem diſconcerted, Mr. Tukely: Has any Thing happen'd?

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: A Trifle, Madam—but I was born to be trifled with, and to be made uneaſy at Trifles.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Pray, what trifling Affair has diſturb'd you thus?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: What's the Matter now?

sp.speaker: TUKLY.
sp.p: I met Miſs Sophy this Moment in a Hackney Chair, at the End of the Street: I knew her by the Pink Negligeè; but upon my croſſing the Way to ſpeak to her, ſhe turn'd her Head away, laugh'd violently, and drew the Curtain in my Face.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: So, ſo; well ſaid, Jealouſy.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: She was in Haſte, I ſuppoſe, to get to her Engagement.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Madam; I imagine ſhe had ſome Engagement upon her Hands—But ſure, Madam, her great Deſire to ſee her more agreeable Friends, need not be attended with Contempt and Diſregard to the reſt of her Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Indeed, Mr. Tukely, I have ſo many Caprices, and Follies of my own, that I can't poſſibly anſwer for my Couſin's too.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Bell.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Anſwer, Miſs!—No, Heav'n forbid you ſhould— for my Part, I have given up all my Hopes as a Lover, and only, now, feel for her as a Friend— and indeed as a Friend, a ſincere Friend—I can't but ſay, that going out in a Hackney Chair, without a Servant, and endeavouring to conceal herſelf, is ſomewhat incompatible with Miſs Sophy's Rank and Reputation —This I ſpeak as a Friend—not as a Lover, Miſs Bell—pray mind that.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: I ſee it very plainly, Mr. Tukely—and it gives me great Pleaſure, that you can be ſo indifferent in your Love, and yet ſo jealous in your Friendſhip.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: You do me Honour, Miſs, by your good Opinion.
Who's that, pray?

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: A Gentleman who is waiting for Sophy.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I think ſhe has Gentlemen waiting for her every where.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I am afraid, Sir, [coming up to him with her Glaſs] you'll excuſe me, that notwithſtanding your Declaration, and this Lady's Compliments, there is a little of the Devil, call'd Jealouſy, at the Bottom of all this Uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Sir!—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I ſay, Sir, wear your Cloak as long as you pleaſe, the Hoof will peep out, take my Word for it.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Upon my Word, Sir, you are pleas'd to honour me with a Familiarity which I neither expected, or indeed deſired, upon ſo ſlight an Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I dare ſwear you did not.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I don't underſtand this!

sp.speaker: ARABELLA:
sp.p: This is beyond Expectation—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I preſume, Sir, you never was out of England—

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I preſume, Sir, that you are miſtaken— I never was ſo fooliſhly fond of my own Country, to think that nothing good was to be had out of it; nor ſo ſhamefully ungrateful to it, to prefer the Vices and Fopperies of every other Nation, to the peculiar Advantages of my own.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Ha, ha; well ſaid, old England, i'faith—Now, Madam, if this Gentleman would put this Speech into a Farce, and properly lard it with Roaſt Beef, and Liberty, I wou'd engage the Galleries wou'd roar and halloo at it for half an Hour together— Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Now the Storm's coming.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: If you are not engag'd, Sir, we'll adjourn to the next Tavern, and write this Farce between us.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I fancy, Sir, by the Information of your Face, that you are more inclin'd to Tragedy, than Comedy—

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I ſhall be inclin'd to treat you very ill, if you don't walk out with me.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I have been treated ſo very ill already, in the little Converſation I have had with you, that you muſt excuſe my walking out for more of it; but if you'll perſuade the Lady to leave the Room, I'll put you to Death—Damme—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake! what's the Matter, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: What can I do with this Fellow?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Madam, don't be alarm'd—this Affair will be very ſhort—I am always expeditious; and will cut his Throat, without ſhocking you in the leaſt: —Come, Sir, [draws] if you won't defend yourſelf, I muſt kick you about the Room.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Reſpect for this Lady, and this Houſe, has curb'd my Reſentment hitherto: But as your Inſolence wou'd take Advantage of my Forbearance, I muſt correct it at all Events—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA and ARABELLA.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: What is all this?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: What, would you ſet your Courage to a poor, weak Woman? You are a bold Briton, indeed!— Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: What, Sophia?—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Sophia! No, no; ſhe is in a Hackney-Chair, you know, without a Servant, in her Pink Negligeè— Ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſh'd! and can ſcarce believe my own Eyes—What means this Metamorphoſis?

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: 'Tis in Obedience to your Commands—Thus equipp'd, I have got Acceſs to Daffodil, and ſhall know whether your Picture of him is drawn by your Regard for me, or Reſentment to him—I will ſound him, from his loweſt Note to the Top of his Compaſs.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Your Spirit tranſports me—This will be a buſy, and, I hope, a happy Day for me. I have appointed no leſs than five Ladies to meet me at the Widow Damply's; to each of whom, as well as yourſelf, the accompliſh'd Mr. Daffodil has preſented his Heart; the Value of which I am reſolved to convince 'em of this Night, for the ſake of the whole Sex.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Pooh, pooh! that's the old Story—You are ſo prejudic'd.—

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I am afraid 'tis you who are prejudic'd, Madam; for if you will believe your own Eyes and Ears—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: That I will, I aſſure you—I ſhall viſit him immediately —He thinks me in the Country, and to confirm it, I'll write to him as from thence—But ask me no more Queſtions about what I have done, and what is to be done; for I have not a Moment to loſe; and ſo, my good Friend Tukely, yours— My dear Bell, I kiſs your Hand— [kiſſes her Hand] You are a fine Woman, by Heav'ns! Here, Joſeppi, Brunello, Franceſi,—where are my Fellows there? Call me a Chair—Viva l'Amòr, & Libertá—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Ha, ha; there's a Spirit for you!—Well now, what do you ſtare at?—You cou'd not well deſire more—O, fie, fie,—don't ſigh, and bite your Fingers; rouze yourſelf, Man; ſet all your Wits to work; bring this faithleſs Corydon to Shame, and I'll be hang'd if the Prize is not yours—If ſhe returns in Time, I'll bring her to the Widow Damply's—

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Dear Miſs Arabella—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Well, well; make me a fine Speech another Time. About your Buſineſs now—

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I fly—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p:
What a Couple of blind Fools has Love made of this poor Fellow, and my dear Couſin Sophy? Little do they imagine, with all their wiſe Diſcoveries, that Daffodil is as faithful a Lover, as he is an accompliſh'd Gentleman—I pity theſe poor deceiv'd Women, with all my Heart—But how will they ſtare, when they find that he has artfully pretended a Regard for them, the better to conceal his real Paſſion
for me—They will certainly tear my Eyes out; and what will Couſin Sophy ſay to me, when we are oblig'd to declare our Paſſion? No Matter what— 'Tis the Fortune of War—And I ſhall only ſerve her, as ſhe and every other Friend wou'd ſerve me in the ſame Situation—
sp.l: A little cheating never is a Sin,
At Love or Cards—provided that you win.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: But are you ſure, Ruffle, that you deliver'd the Letter laſt Night, in the Manner I order'd you?

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: Exactly, Sir.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: And you are ſure that Mr. Dotterel ſaw you ſlip the Note into his Wife's Hand?

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: I have alarm'd him, and you may be aſſur'd, that he is as uneaſy as you wou'd wiſh to have him—But I ſhou'd be glad, with your Honour's Leave, to have a little ſerious Converſation with you; for my Mind forebodes much Peril to the Bones of your humble Servant, and very little Satisfaction to your Honour.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Thou art a moſt incomprehenſible Blockhead—

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: No great Scholar, or Wit, indeed—but I can feel an Oak Sappling, as well as another—Ay, and I ſhou'd have felt one laſt Night, if I had not had the Heels of all Mr. Dotterel's Family—I had the whole Pack after me—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: And did not they catch you?

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: No, thank Heaven—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: You was not kick'd then?

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Nor can'd?

sp.speaker: RUFLLE.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Nor drag'd thro' a Horſe-pond?

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: O, Lord! No, Sir.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: That's unlucky—

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: You muſt go again, Ruffle, to Night, perhaps you may be in better Luck.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p:
If I go again, Sir, may I be can'd, kick'd, and Horſe-ponded for my Pains—I believe I have been
• ucky enough to bring an old Houſe over your Head.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: What d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p:
Mr. Dotterel only hobbled after me, to pay me
〈◊〉 the Poſtage of your Letter; but being a little out
〈◊〉 Wind, he ſoon ſtopt, to curſe and ſwear at me—
I cou'd hear him mutter ſomething of Scoundrel, and Pimp, and my Maſter, and Villain—and Blunderbuſs, and Saw-pit; and then he ſhook his Stick, and look'd like the Devil!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Blunderbuſs, and Saw-pit! This Buſineſs grows a little ſerious, and ſo we will drop it—The Husband is ſo old and peeviſh, and ſhe ſo young and preſſing, that I'll give it up, Ruffle—The Town talks of us, and I am ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: Pray Sir, with Submiſſion, for what End do you write to ſo many Ladies, and make ſuch a Rout about 'em; there are now upon the Liſt half a Dozen Maids, a Leaſh of Wives, and the Widow Damply. I know your Honour don't intend Miſchief; but what Pleaſure can you have in deceiving them, and the World? for you are thought a terrible young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Why that Pleaſure, Booby.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: I don't underſtand it—What do you intend to do with 'em all? Ruin 'em?

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Not I, faith.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: But you'll ruin their Reputations.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: That's their Buſineſs—Not mine.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: Will you marry any one of 'em?

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p:
O, no; that wou'd be finiſhing the Game at once—If I preferr'd one, the Reſt wou'd take it
ill; ſo becauſe I won't be particular, I give 'em all Hopes, without going a Step further.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: Widows can't live upon ſuch ſlender Diet.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: A true Sportſman has no Pleaſure but in the Chace; the Game is always given to thoſe who have leſs Taſte, and better Stomachs.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: I love to pick a Bit, I muſt confeſs—Really, Sir, I ſhou'd not care what became of half the Women you are pleas'd to be merry with—But Miſs Sophy, ſure, is a heavenly Creature, and deſerves better Treatment; and to make Love to her Couſin too, in the ſame Houſe—that is very cruel.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: But it amuſes one—beſides they are both fine Creatures. And how do I know, if I lov'd only one, but the other might poiſon herſelf?

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: And when they know that you have lov'd 'em both, they may poiſon one another—This Affair will make a great Noiſe.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Or I have taken a great Deal of Pains for nothing; but no more prating, Sirrah; while I read my Letters, go and ask Harry what Cards and Meſſages he has taken in this Morning.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: There is no mending him.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p:
[Opens Letters] This is from the Widow Damply —I know her Scrawl at a Mile's Diſtance—ſhe pretends that the Fright of her Husband's Death hurt
her Nerves ſo, that her Hand has ſhook ever ſince— ha, ha, ha—It has hurt her Spelling too, for here is Joy with a G; ha! ha! poor Creature. [Reads] Hum—hum—hum—Well ſaid, Widow; ſhe ſpeaks plain, faith, and grows urgent—I muſt get quit of her—ſhe deſires a tête à tête; which, with Widows who have ſuffered much for the Loſs of their Husbands, is, as Capt. Bobadil ſays, a Service of Danger. So, I am off— [Opens another] What the Devil have we here? A Bill in Chancery: Oh, no! my Taylor's Bill—Sum Total 374l. 11s. 5¾d. —Indeed, Monſieur Chicaneau, this is a damn'd Bill, and you will be damn'd for making it—therefore, for the Good of your Soul, Monſ. Chicaneau, you muſt make another. [tears it] The French know their Conſequence, and uſe us accordingly. [Opens another.] This is from Newmarket.— [Reads]—

body.p: I Wou'd not have you think of matching Cherry-Derry with Gingerbread; he is a terrible Horſe, and very covetous of his Ground—I have chopt Hurlothrumbo for the Roan Mare, and fifty Pounds. Sir Roger has taken the Match off your Hands, which is a good Thing; for the Mare has the Diſtemper, and muſt have forfeited—I flung his Honour's Groom, tho' he was above an Hour in the Stable. The Nutmeg Grey, Cuſtard, is match'd with Alderman. Alderman has a good Wind, and will be too hard for Cuſtard.—

closer.signed: I am, your Honour's Moſt obedient Servant, ROGER WHIP.

sp.p: —Whip's a Genius, and a good Servant. I have not as yet loſt above a Thouſand Pounds by my Horſes—But ſuch Luck can't always laſt.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: There's the Morning's Cargo, Sir.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Heigh Day! I can't read 'em in a Month; prithee, Ruffle, ſet down my Invitations from the Cards, according to their Date, and let me ſee 'em Tomorrow Morning—So much Reading wou'd diſtract me.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: And yet theſe are the only Books that Gentlemen read Now-a-Days.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: And pleaſe your Honour, I forgot to tell you that there was a Gentleman here laſt Night—I've forgot his Name.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: Old Mr. Dotterel, perhaps.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Old; no, no, he looks younger than his Honour —I believe he's mad, he can't ſtand ſtill a Moment; he firſt caper'd out of the Chair, and when I told him your Honour was not at Home, he caper'd into it again—ſaid he would call again, jabber'd ſomething, and away he went ſinging.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: 'Tis the Marquis of Macaroni, I ſaw him at the King's Arms Yeſterday: Admit him when he comes, Harry.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: I ſhall, your Honour—I can neither write or remember theſe outlandiſh Names.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Where is my Liſt of Women, Ruffle, and the Places of their Abode, that we may ſtrike off ſome, and add the new Acquiſitions?

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: What, alter again! I wrote it out fair but this Morning—There are quicker Succeſſions in your Honour's Liſt, than the Court-Calendar.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Strike off Mrs. Dotterel, and the Widow Damply.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: They are undone.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: A Lady, Mr. Ruffle, in a Chair, muſt ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Did ſhe ask for me?—See Ruffle, who it is.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: No, your Honour; but ſhe look'd quite fluſtrated.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Well, go below, and be careful not to let any old Gentleman in this Morning—and d'ye hear, if any of the Neighbours ſhou'd inquire who the Lady is, you may ſay it is a Relation; and be ſure ſmile, do you hear? when you tell 'em ſo.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: I ſhall, your Honour—He, he, he, I am never melancholy.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: That Fellow's a Character.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: Sir, it is Mrs. Dotterel; ſhe has had a terrible Quarrel with her Husband about your Letter, and has ſomething to ſay of Conſequence to you both— ſhe muſt ſee you, ſhe ſays.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I won't ſee her—Why wou'd you ſay that I was at Home—You know I hate to be alone with 'em, and ſhe's ſo violent too—Well, well, ſhew her up—This is ſo unlucky—

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: He hates to ſee Duns he never intends to pay.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: What ſhall I do with her? This is worſe than meeting her Husband with a Blunderbuſs in a Saw-pit.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Dotterel, this is ſo obliging—Ruffle, don't let a Soul come near me. [Aloud]—And harkee, don't leave us long together, and let every Body up that comes.

sp.speaker: RUFFLE.
sp.p: What a Deal of Trouble here is about nothing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: In the Name of Virtue, Mr. Daffodil, I hope you have not given any private Orders, that may in the leaſt derogate from that abſolute Confidence which I place in your Honour.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p:
You may be perfectly eaſy under this Roof, Madam. I hope, I am polite enough not to let my Paſſions,
of any Kind, run too great Lengths in my own Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Nothing but abſolute Neceſſity cou'd have made me take this imprudent Step—I am ready to faint with my Apprehenſions—Heigh ho!—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Heav'n forbid!—I'll call for ſome Aſſiſtance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Let your Bell alone [Stopping him] You'r always calling for Aſſiſiſtance, I think—you never give one Time to come to ones ſelf—Mr. Dotterel has ſeen your Letter, and vows Vengeance and Deſtruction— Why wou'd you be ſo violent and imprudent?

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: The Devil was in me, Madam; but I repent it from my Soul; it has cur'd me of being violent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Come, come, don't take it too deeply neither; I thought it proper, at all Hazards, to let you know what had happen'd, and to intreat you, by that Affection you have ſworn to me, to be careful of my Reputation.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: That I will indeed, Madam; we can't be too careful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Daffodil, I am an unhappy Woman— married to one I cannot love; and loving one I ought to ſhun—It is a terrible Situation, Mr. Daffodil—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: It is indeed, Madam,—I am in a terrible one too —Wou'd I was well out of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p:
Do you know, Mr. Daffodil, that if I had not been
very religious, my Paſſions would have undone me— But you muſt give me Time, for nothing but that, and keeping the beſt Company, will ever conquer my Prejudices—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I ſhould be very ungenerous not to allow you Time, Madam—three Weeks or a Month, I hope, will do the Buſineſs—Tho', by my Honour, I got the better of Mine in half the Time—What is Ruffle doing?

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: He's very cold, methinks; but I'll try him further —Lookee, Mr. Daffodil, you muſt curb your Paſſions, and keep your Diſtance—Fire is catching, and one does not know the Conſequences when once it begins to ſpread.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: As you ſay, Madam, Fire is a catching; 'tis dangerous to play with it; and as I am of the Tinder-Kind, —as one may ſay,—we had better,—as you ſay—Madam,—change the Subject—Pray did you ever hear of the Pug-dog that you advertis'd? It was a very pretty Creature—what was his Name, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Daffodil, Sir!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Could I love and eſteem any Thing, and not call it Daffodil?—What a Wretch!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: You do me Honour, Madam—I don't like her Looks, I muſt change the Diſcourſe [Aſide.] Upon my Soul, Mrs. Dotterel, this Struggle is too much for Man: My Paſſions are now tearing me to Pieces, and if you will ſtay, by Heav'n I will not anſwer for the Conſequences.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Conſequences! What Conſequences! Thou wretched, baſe, falſe, worthleſs Animal!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: You do me Honour.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Canſt thou think that I am ſo blinded by my Paſſion, not to ſee thy treacherous, mean, unmanly Evaſions?—I have long ſuſpected your Infamy, and having this Proof of it, I cou'd ſtab your treacherous Heart, and my own weak one—Don't offer to ſtir, or ring your Bell, for, by Heav'ns, I'll—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I ſtir! I am never ſo happy, as when I am in your Company.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Thou lieſt: Thou art never ſo happy as when thou art deceiving, and betraying our fooliſh Sex—and all for what? Why, for the poor Reputation of having that, which thou haſt neither Power nor Spirit to enjoy.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Ha! I hear Somebody coming—Now for a Rapure [Aſide.] Talk not of Power or Spirit—Heav'n, that has made you fair, has made me ſtrong—O! forgive the Madneſs which your Beauty has occaſion'd.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: The Marquis of Macaroons—

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Ha! [Screams.] I am betray'd!—
sp.stage: [They all ſtare, and DAFFODIL ſeemingly aſtoniſhed.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Mrs. Dotterel, by all that's virtuous— [Aſide] Signor Daffodillo—reſto Confuſo, tat I am com ſi mal-a propoſito.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Dear Marquis, no Excuſe I beg—nothing at all— a Relation of mine—my Siſter only—Miſs Daffodil, this is, il Mercheſe de Macaroni, an Intimate of Sir Charles Vainlove's—This was lucky [Aſide]—Well, then, my dear Siſter, I will wait upon you To-morrow, and ſettle the whole Affair. [Aloud] I am the moſt miſerable of Mortals, and have loſt the moſt precious Moments of my Life.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: You are a Villain—I deſpiſe you, and deteſt you—and will never ſee you more.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!—My Siſter has a noble Spirit, my Lord.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Mi diſpiace infinamente—it tisplis me, tat I haf interrumpato, gli Affari of you Famili.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: It is the old Family-buſineſs, my Lord; and ſo old, that, by my Honour, I am quite tir'd of it.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I hate him already. [Aſide.]—Signor Daffodillo, ſhe is una beliſſima Sorella in Verità, a very prit' Siſs' intit.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs to you, my Lord, that my Siſter is a young diſtreſs'd Damſel, married to an old Gentleman of the Neighbourhood, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p:
O Cara Inghilterra! vat a fortunata Contreé is tis!
te olt Men marri de yong fine Girl, and te yong fine Girl viſite te yong Signors—O, precioſa Libertà!—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, Men of Faſhion here have ſome ſmall Privileges; we gather our Roſes without fear of Thorns—Husbands and Brothers don't deal in Poiſon and Stilletos, as they do with you.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Il noſtro amico, Signor Carlo, has tol me a touſant Volti, dat you vas de Orlando Innamorato himſelf.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: But not Furioſo, I can aſſure you, my Lord, Ha, ha, ha! I am for Variety, and Badinage, without Affection —Reputation is the great Ornament, and Eaſe the great Happineſs of Life—To ruin Women wou'd be troubleſome; to trifle and make Love to 'em amuſes one—I uſe my Women as daintily as my Tokay; I merely ſip of both, but more than half a Glaſs palls me.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Il mio proprio Guſto—Tukely is right; he's a Villain. [Aſide]—Signor Daffodillo; Vil you do me de Favor to give me Stranger, una Introduzione to ſome of your Signorine, let voſtro amico taſte a littel, un Poco of your dulce Tokay.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: O, Certamente!—I have half a hundred Signorines at your Service.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Multo obligato, Signor Daffodillo.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Here is a Letter for your Honour.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: What is the Matter with the Fellow?

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Matter, your Honour!—the Lady that went out juſt now, gave me ſuch a Souſe on the Ear, as I made my Bow to her, that I cou'd ſcarce tell, for a Minute, whether I had a Head or no.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—Poor Fellow!—there's Smart Money for you. [Gives him Money.]— [Exit Servant.]—Will your Lordſhip give me Leave?—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Senza Ceremonie—now for it.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.

body.p: I Shall return from the Country next Week, and ſhall hope to meet you at Lady Fanny Pewit's Aſſembly next Wedneſday.

closer.signed: I am very much your humble Servant, SOPHIA SPRIGHTLY.

sp.p: —My Lord Marquis, here is a Letter has ſtarted Game for you already—the moſt lucky Thought imaginable.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Coſa é queſta—Coſa, é—vat is?

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p:
There are two fine Girls you muſt know, Couſins, who live together; this is a Letter from one of 'em, Sophia is her Name—I have addreſs'd 'em both, but as Matters become a little ſerious on their
Side, I muſt raiſe a Jealouſy between the Friends; diſcover to one the Treachery of the other; and ſo in the Buſtle ſteal off as quietly as I can.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: O! Spiritoſo Amico—I can ſcarce contain myſelf.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Before the Mine is ſprung, I will introduce you into the Town.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: You are great Generaliſſimo in verità mà. I feel in miò Core vat de poor infelice Sophia vil feel for de Loſs of Signor Daffadillo.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Yes, poor Creature; I believe ſhe'll have a Pang or two—tender indeed! and I believe will be unhappy for ſome Time.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: What a Monſter!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: You muſt dine with our Club to-day, where I will introduce you to more of Sir Charles's Friends, all Men of Figure and Faſhion.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I muſt primo haf my Lettere, dat your Amici may be aſſicurati dat I am no Impoſtore.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: In the Name of Politeneſs, my Lord Marquis, don't mention your Letters again; none but a Juſtice of Peace, or a Conſtable, would ever ask for a Certificate of a Man's Birth, Parentage, and Education, Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Viva, viva il Signor Daffodillo! You ſhall be il mio Conduttorè in tutte le Partite of Love and Pleaſure.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: With all my Heart—You muſt give me Leave now, my Lord, to put on my Cloaths—In the mean Time, if your Lordſhip will ſtep into my Study there, if you chuſe Muſic, there is a Guittar, and ſome Venetian Ballads; or, if you like reading, there's Infidelity, and baudy Novels for you—Call Ruffle there.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: [Looking after him] I am ſhock'd at him—He is really more abandon'd than Tukely's Jealouſy deſcrib'd him—I have got my Proofs, and will not venture any further; I am vex'd that I ſhou'd be angry at him, when I ſhou'd only deſpiſe him—But I am ſo angry, that I cou'd almoſt wiſh myſelf a Man, that my Breeches might demand Satisfaction for the Injury he has done my Petticoats.—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: IN ſhort, his own Declarations, the unexpected Meeting of Mrs. Dotterel, his Uſage of my Letter, and twenty Things beſide, determin'd me not to go among the Set of 'em—So making the beſt Excuſe I cou'd, I got quit of him and his Companions.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: All this may be true, Sophy—Every young Fellow has his Vanities; Faſhion has made ſuch Irregularities Accompliſhments, and the Man may be worth having, for all your Diſcoveries.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: What! an abandon'd, raſh, profligate Male-Coquette; a Wretch, who can aſſume Paſſions he never feels, and ſport with our Sex's Frailties—Fie, fie, Bell.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Well, well, you are too angry to be merciful— If he is ſuch a Monſter, I am glad you are out of his Clutches, and that you can ſo eaſily reſign him to another.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p:
To another! there is not that Woman, be ſhe ever ſo handſome, that I hate enough, to wiſh her ſo much
Evil; and happy it is for you, Bell, that you have a Heart to reſiſt his Allurements.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Yes, I thank my Stars—I am not ſo ſuſceptible of Impreſſions of that Kind—and yet—I won't ſwear—if an agreeable Man—I—I—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: No, no, Bell, you are not abſolute Stone—you you may be mollified—She is confounded—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Surely he has not betray'd me—'Tis impoſſible, I cannot be deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Well, ſhall we go in to the Ladies and Mr. Tukely? Were they not ſurpriz'd when he open'd the Buſineſs to 'em?

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: 'Twas the fineſt Scene imaginable—You cou'd ſee, tho' they all endeavour'd to hide their Liking to Daffodil, all were uneaſy at Tukely's Diſcovery. At firſt, they objected to his Scheme; but they began to liſten to his Propoſal the Moment I was call'd out to you; what farther he intends, is a Secret to us all; but here he comes, and without the Ladies.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Pray, Miſs Bell—Bleſs me! Miſs Sophy return'd! I dare not ask—and yet if my Eyes do not flatter my Heart—your Looks—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Don't rely too much upon Looks, Mr. Tukely.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Madam—why ſure—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Don't imagine, I ſay, that you can always ſee the Mind in the Face.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I can ſee, Madam, that your Mind is not diſpos'd to wiſh, or make me happy.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Did not I bid you not to rely upon Looks; for do you know now that my Mind is at this Time moſt abſolutely diſpos'd—to do every thing that you wou'd have me.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Then I have nothing more to wiſh or ask of Fortune.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Come, come, this is no Time to attend to one, when you have ſo many Ladies to take Care of.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I will not yet enquire into your Adventures, 'till I have accompliſh'd my own. The Ladies within have at laſt agreed, to attend me this Evening; where, if you have a Mind to finiſh the Picture you have begun this Morning, an Opportunity may offer.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I am contented with my Sketch—However, I'll make one; and if you have an Occaſion for a Second in any thing—I am your Man—command me.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: A Match—from this Moment I take you as my Second; nay, my Firſt in every Circumſtance of our future Lives.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Mighty pretty, truly!—and ſo I am to ſtand cooling my Heels here, while you are making yourſelves ridiculous.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA:
sp.p: Bell's in the Right—to Buſineſs, to Buſineſs— Mr. Tukeley, you muſt introduce me to the Ladies; I can at leaſt make as good a Figure as Mr. Daffodil among 'em.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: When Daffodil's real Inclinations are known, how thoſe poor Wretches will be diſappointed.

div.stage: Lord RACKET, Sir TAN-TIVY, Sir WILLIAM WHISTER, SPINNER writing, and DAFFODIL.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: What do you ſay, my Lord, that I don't do it in an Hour?

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Not in an Hour and Half, George.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Done with you, my Lord—I'll take your Seven to Five—Seventy Poud to Fifty.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Done—I'll lay the Odds again, with you, Sir William—and with you, Sir Tivy.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Not I, faith;—Daffodil has too many fine Women —he'll never do it.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I'll go into the Country for a Week, and not a Petticoat ſhal come near me—I'll take the Odds again.

sp.speaker: Sir TAN-TIVY.
sp.p: Done, Daffodil.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: You are to hop upon one Leg, without changing, mind that—Set it down, Spinner.

sp.speaker: SPINNER.
sp.p: I have—Shall I read it?

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Silence in the Court.

body.p: Lord Racket has betted 70 Pounds to 50, with the Honourable George Daffodil— that the Latter does not walk from Bukingham-Gate, to the Bun-houſe, at Chelſea—eat a Bun there, run back to the Turnpike, and from thence hop upon one Leg, with the other tied to the Cue of his Wig, to Buckingham-Gate again, in an Hour and Half.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I ſay, done—

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: And done.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Conſider your Women—you'll never do it, George.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Not do it! [hops] Why, I'll get a Chelſea Penſioner ſhall do it in an Hour, with his wooden Leg—What Day ſhall we fix for it?

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: The firſt of April, to be ſure.

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.—

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Come, Daffodil, read the Betts and Matches of Today —then let us finiſh our Champaigne, and go to the Opera.

body.p: March 24, 1757, Sir Tan-Tivy, has pitted Lady Pettitoe, againſt Dowager Lady Periwinkle, with Sir William Whiſter, for 500l.—I'll pit my Uncle. Lord Chalkſtone, againſt 'em both.

sp.speaker: Sir TAN-TIVY.
sp.p: Done.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: The Odds are againſt you, Daffodil—my Lord has got to plain Nantz now every Morning.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: And the Ladies have been at it to my Knowledge, this half Year.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Good, again, George.

body.p: The Honourable George Daffodil, has betted one hundred Pound, with Sir William Whiſter, that he produces a Gentleman, before the 5th of June next, that ſhall live for five Days ſucceſſively, without Eating, Drinking, or Sleeping.—

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: He muſt have no Books, George.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: No, no; the Gentleman I mean can't read.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: 'Tis not yourſelf, George!

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; 'tis impoſſible, it muſt kill him.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Why, then I loſe my Bet.

body.p: Lord Racket has match'd Sir Joſlin Jolly againſt Major Calipaſh, with Sir Tan-Tivy, to run fifty Yards upon the Mall after Dinner, if either tumbles, the Wages is loſt—for Fifty Pounds.

sp.speaker: SPINNER.
sp.p: I'll lay Fifty more, neither of 'em run the Ground in Half an Hour.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Not in an Hour.

sp.speaker: Sir TAN-TIVY.
sp.p: Done, Daffodil—I'll bet you a Hundred of that.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Done, Baronet; I'll double it, if you will.

sp.speaker: Sir TAN-TIVY.
sp.p: With all my Heart—Book it, Spinner.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: You'll certainly loſe, George.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Impoſſible, my Lord; Sir Joſlin is damnably out of Wind.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: What, Aſthmatic?

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: No, quite cur'd of his Aſthma—he dy'd Yeſterday Morning—Bite.

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Bravo, George.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Now you talk of dying—how does your Couſin Dizzy?

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Lingers on—better and worſe—Lives upon Aſſes Milk, Panada, and Eringo Root.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: You'll have a fine Wind-fall there, George—a good Two Thouſand a Year.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: 'Tis better, my Lord; but I love Dick ſo well, and have had ſo many Obligations to him—he ſav'd my Life once—that I cou'd wiſh him better Health.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Or in a better Place—there's deviliſh fine Timber in Staunton Woods.

sp.speaker: Sir TAN-TIVY.
sp.p: Down with 'em, Daffodil.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: But let Dizzy drop firſt—a little Blaſt will fell him.

sp.speaker: DIZZY.
sp.p: Not ſo little as you may imagine, my Lord—hugh, hugh—

sp.speaker: ALL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Angels and Miniſters! what Couſin! We were got among your Trees.

sp.speaker: DIZZY.
sp.p: You are heartily welcome to any one of 'em, Gentlemen, for a proper Purpoſe—hugh, hugh.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Well ſaid, Dick. How quick his Wit, and how youthful the Rogue looks!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Bloomy and plump—the Country Air is a fine Thing, my Lord—

sp.speaker: DIZZY.
sp.p: Well, well, be as jocular as you pleaſe; I am not ſo ill, as you may wiſh, or imagine;—I can walk to Knightsbridge in an Hour, for a Hundred Pound.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: I bet you a Hundred of that, Dizzy.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I'll lay you a Hundred, Dick, that I drive a Sow and Pigs to your Lodgings, before you can get there.

sp.speaker: DIZZY.
sp.p: Done, I ſay; [Draws his Purſe.] Done—Two Hundred—done—Three.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: I'll take Dizzy, againſt your Sow and Pigs.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: I take the Field againſt Dizzy.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Done.

sp.speaker: SPINNER.
sp.p: Done.

sp.speaker: DIZZY.
sp.p: Damn your Sow and Pigs; I am ſo ſick with the Thoughts of runing with 'em, that I ſhall certainly faint— [Smells to a Bottle]—hugh, hugh—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Couſin Dizzy can't bear the Mention of Pork— he hates it—I knew it would work.

sp.speaker: DIZZY.
sp.p: I wiſh you had not mention'd it—I can't ſtay —Damn your Sow and Pigs—Here, Waiter, call a Chair—Damn your Sow and Pigs!—hugh, hugh.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Poor Dizzy—What a Paſſion he is in!—Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: The Woods are yours, George; you may whet the Axe—Dizzy won't live a Month.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Pooh, this is nothing—he was always weakly—

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: 'Tis a Family Misfortune, Daffodil.

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: Mr. Dizzy, Gentlemen, dropp'd down at the Stair Foot, and the Cook has carried him behind the Bar.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Lay him upon a Bed, and he'll come to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: I'll bet Fifty Pound, that he don't live till Morning.

sp.speaker: SIR WILLIAM.
sp.p: I'll lay Six to Four, he don't live a Week.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I'll take your Fifty Pound.

sp.speaker: SPINNER.
sp.p: I'll take your Lordſhip again.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Done, with you both.

sp.speaker: Sir TAN-TIVY.
sp.p: I'll take it again.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Done, done, done;—but I bar all Aſſiſtance to him—Not a Phyſician, or Surgeon ſent for— or I am off.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: No, no; we are upon Honour—There ſhall be none, elſe it wou'd be a bubble Bet.—There ſhall be none.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: If I were my Lord, now, the Phyſicians ſhould attend him.

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: A Letter for his Honour—

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: Daffodil, remember the Firſt of April—and let the Women alone.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Upon my Soul you have hit it—'tis a Woman, faith—Something very particular, and if you are in Spirits for a Scheme—

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Ay, ay; come, come; a Scheme, a Scheme!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: There then, have among you.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p:
Reads, all looking on.] Hum—
If the liking your Perſon be a Sin, what Woman is not guilty?—hum hum—at the End of the Bird-cage Walk—
about Seven—where the Darkneſs and Privacy will befriend my Bluſhes; I will convince you, what Truſt I have in your Secrecy and Honour—
Yours, INCOGNITA.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Will you go?

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: What do you propoſe?

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: To go—If after I have been with her half an Hour, you'll come upon us—and have a Blow up.

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: There's a Gallant for you!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Prithee, Sir William, be quiet—muſt a Man be in Love with every Woman that invites him!

sp.speaker: Sir WILLIAM.
sp.p: No; but he ſhould be honourable to 'em, George— and rather conceal a Woman's Weakneſs, than expoſe it—I hate this Work—ſo, I'll go to the Coffee-houſe.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Let him go—don't mind him, George; he's married, and paſt fifty—this will be a fine Frolic—Deviliſh high—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Very!—Well, I'll go and prepare myſelf—put on my Surtout, and take my Chair to Buckingham-Gate —I know the very Spot.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: We'll come with Flambeaux—you muſt be ſurpris'd, and—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I know what to do—Here, Waiter, Waiter;
How does Couſin Dizzy?

sp.speaker: WAITER.
sp.p: Quite recover'd, Sir;—he is in the Phoenix, with two Ladies, and has order'd a boil'd Chicken and Jellies.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: There's a Blood for you!—without a Drop in his Veins.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Do you ſtay with him, then, till I have ſecur'd my Lady; and in Half an Hour from this Time come away, and bring Dizzy with you.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: If he'll leave the Ladies—Don't the Italian Marquis dine with us To-morrow?

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Well, do you mind your Buſineſs—and I'll ſpeak to the Cook to ſhew his Genius—Allons!

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Tom, bid the Cook attend me To-morrow Morning, on ſpecial Affairs—

sp.speaker: 2d WAITER.
sp.p: I ſhall, my Lord.

sp.speaker: 1ſt WAITER.
sp.p: I'll lay you, Tom, Five Six-pences to Three, that my Lord wins his Bett with his Honour Daffodil.

sp.speaker: 2d WAITER.
sp.p: Done with you Harry—I'll take your Half Crown to Eighteen-pence—

sp.speaker: 1ſt WAITER.
sp.p: Coming, Sir;—I'll make it Shillings, Tom.

sp.speaker: 2d WAITER.
sp.p: No, Harry, you've the beſt on't. [Bell rings.] Coming, Sir. I'll take Five Shillings to Two. [Bell rings] Coming, Sir.—

sp.speaker: 1ſt WAITER.
sp.p: Coming, Sir.—No, Five to Three.

sp.speaker: 2d WAITER.
sp.p: Shillings?—Coming, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1ſt WAITER.
sp.p: No—Sixpences—

sp.speaker: 2d WAITER.
sp.p: Done—Sixpences. [Bell rings.] Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: 1ſt WAITER.
sp.p: And done. [Bell rings.] Coming, Sir.

div.stage: Enter ARABELLA, Mrs. DAMPLY, Lady FAN. PEWIT, Mrs. DOTTEREL, TUKELY in Womens Cloaths, and SOPHIA in Mens.

sp.speaker: Ladies ALL.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: What a Figure! And what a Scheme.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Dear Ladies, be as merry with my Figure as you pleaſe—Yet you ſhall ſee, this Figure, awkward as it is, ſhall be preferr'd in its Turn, as well as you have been.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Why will you give yourſelf this unneceſſary Trouble, Mr. Tukely, to convince theſe Ladies, who had rather ſtill be deluded, and will hate your Friendſhip for breaking the Charm.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: My dear Couſin, tho' you are ſatisfied, theſe Ladies are not; and if they have their particular Reaſons for their Infidelity; pray, let 'em enjoy it, 'till they have other Proofs than your Prejudices.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Ay, Bell, we have all our Prejudices.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: What ſignifies reaſoning, when we are going upon the Experiment? Diſpoſe of yourſelves behind thoſe Trees, and I will repair to the Place of Appointment, and draw him hither; but you promiſe to contain yourſelves, let what will happen. Hear, and ſee; but be ſilent.—

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: A ſevere Injunction, indeed, Ladies—But I muſt to my Poſt.

sp.speaker: Widow DAMPLY.
sp.p: If he's a Villain, I can never hold!

sp.speaker: Lady PEWIT.
sp.p: I ſhall tear his Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: For my Part, if I was unmarried, I ſhould not think him worth my Anger.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: But as you are, Madam—

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: I underſtand your Inſinuations, Miſs Bell; but my Character and Conduct need no Juſtification.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: I beg Pardon, Madam; I intended no Offence.— But haſte to your Poſts, Ladies; the Enemy's at Hand.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p:
In a Woman's Voice.] For Heaven's Sake, let 〈◊〉
be cautious—I am ſure I heard a Noiſe.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: 'Twas nothing but your Fear, my Angel!— don't be alarm'd—There can be no Danger, while we have Love and Darkneſs to befriend us.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Bleſs me, how my Heart beats!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Poor Soul! what a Fright it is in!—You muſt not give Way to theſe Alarms—Were you as well convinc'd of my Honour, as I am of your Charms, you wou'd have nothing to fear—

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Upon my Word!—

sp.speaker: Widow DAMPLY.
sp.p: So, ſo, ſo.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, you muſt take no Liberties—But, if you have the leaſt Feeling for an unhappy Woman, urg'd by her Paſſion to this imprudent Step, aſſiſt me—forgive me—let me go.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Can you doubt my Honour? Can you doubt my Love? What Aſſurances can I give you to abate your Fears?

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Very ſlender Ones, I can aſſure her.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I deſerve to ſuffer all I feel—For what, but the moſt blinded Paſſion, cou'd induce me to declare myſelf to one, whoſe Amours and Infidelities are the common Topic of Converſation.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Flattering Creature! [Aſide.]—May I never know your dear Name, ſee your charming Face, touch your ſoft Hand, or hear your ſweet Voice, if I am not more ſincere in my Affection for this little Finger, than for all the Sex beſides.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Except the Widow Damply—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: She!—Do you know her, Madam;

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I have not that Honour—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I thought ſo—Did you never ſee her, Madam, nodling and gogling in her Old-faſhion'd heavy Chariot, drawn by a pair of lean hackney Horſes, with a fat Blackamoor Footman behind, in a ſcanty Livery, Red greaſy Stockings, and a dirty Turban?

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: All which may be only a Foil to her Beauty.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Beauty! Don't ſigh, Madam; ſhe is paſt Forty, wears a Wig, and has loſt two of her fore Teeth. —And then, ſhe has ſo long a Beard upon her upper Lip, and takes ſo much Spaniſh Snuff, that ſhe looks, for all the World, like the Great Mogul in Petticoats; ha, ha,—

sp.speaker: Widow DAMPLY.
sp.p: What Falſhood and Ingratitude!

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Cou'd I deſcend to the Slander of the Town, there is a married Lady—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Poor Mrs. Dotterel, you mean—

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Why am I to be mentioned!—I have nothing to do—

sp.speaker: Widow DAMPLY.
sp.p: Nay, nay; you muſt have your Share of the Panegyrick.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: She is young, and has Wit.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: She's an Ideot, Madam; and as Fools are generally loving, ſhe has forgot all her Obligations to old Mr. Dotterel, who married her without a Petticoat; and now ſeizes upon every young Fellow ſhe can lay her Hands upon; ſhe has ſpoil'd me three Suits of Cloaths, with tearing the Flaps and Sleeves. —Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: Monſter of Iniquity!—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: She has even ſtorm'd me in my own Houſe; but with all my Faults, Madam, you'll never find me over-fond of Age, or Ignorance.

sp.speaker: Widow DAMPLY.
sp.p: I cou'd tear him to Pieces.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: I will tear him to Pieces.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Be quiet—and we'll all tear him to Pieces.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: He has ſwallow'd the Hook, and can't eſcape.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: What do you ſay, Madam?

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I am only ſighing, Sir.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Fond Creature! [Aſide.] I know there are a thouſand Stories about me: You have heard too of Lady Fanny Pewit, I ſuppoſe? Don't be alarm'd.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I can't help it, Sir. She is a fine Woman, and Woman of Quality.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: A fine Woman, perhaps, for a Woman of Quality —but ſhe is an abſolute old Maid, Madam, almoſt as thick as ſhe is long—middle-aged, homely and wanton! That's her Character.

sp.speaker: Lady PEWIT.
sp.p: Then there is no Sincerity in Man.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Poſitively, you ſhan't ſtir.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Upon my Soul, I pity the poor Creature!— She is now upon her laſt Legs.—If ſhe does not run away with ſome fooliſh Gentleman this Winter —She'll return into the Country, and marry her Footman.—Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady PEWIT.
sp.p: My Footman ſhall break his Bones, I can tell him that.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Huſh, Madam! I proteſt, I thought I heard a Voice—I wonder they don't come.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: 'Twas only I, Mr. Daffodil—I was murmuring to you.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Pretty Murmurer!—Egad, if they don't come ſoon, the Lady will grow fond.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: But among your Conqueſts, Mr. Daffodil, you forget Miſs Sophy Sprightly.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: And her Couſin Arabella.—I was coming to 'em; poor, ſilly, good-natur'd, loving Fools;— I made my Addreſſes to one thro' Pique, and the other for Pity—That was all.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: O, that I could believe you.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Don't be uneaſy, I'll tell you how it was, Madam —You muſt know, there is a ſilly, ſelf-ſufficient Fellow, one Tukely—

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: So, ſo, [Aſide.] I know him a little.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I am ſorry for it—The leſs you know of him the better; the Fellow pretended to look fierce at me, for which I reſolv'd to have his Miſtreſs: So I threw in my Line, and without much Trouble, hook'd her. Her poor Couſin too, nibbled at the Bait, and was caught.—So I have had my Revenge upon Tukely, and now I ſhall willingly reſign poor Sophy, and throw him in her Couſin, for a Make-Weight. —Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lady PEWIT.
sp.p: This is ſome Comfort at leaſt.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip is better than you was.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I vow I hear a Noiſe.—What ſhall we do? It comes this Way.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: They can't ſee us, my Dear.—I wiſh my Friends would come. [Aſide.] Don't whiſper or breath.

div.stage: Enter SOPHIA, in a Surtout, and ſlouch'd Hat.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p:
If I cou'd but catch her at her Pranks—ſhe certainly muſt be this Way—for the Chair is
waiting at the End of Roſamond's Pond—I have thrown one of her Chairmen into it—and if I cou'd but catch her—

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
DAFFODIL.
sp.p: The Devil it is! Why then, Madam, the beſt Way will be for you to go to him—and let me ſneak off the other Way.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: Go to him, Sir! What can I ſay to him?

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Any Thing, Madam—ſay you had the Vapours, and wanted Air.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
SOPHIA.
sp.p: If I cou'd but catch her—

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: For your Sake, Madam, I'll make the beſt of my Way Home—

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: What! wou'd you leave me to the Fury of an enrag'd Husband!—Is that your Affection.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: If I cou'd but catch her—Ha! what's that? I ſaw ſomething move in the Dark—the Point of my Sword ſhall tickle it out, whatever it is.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: For Heaven's Sake draw, and fight him, while I make my Eſcape.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Fight him!—'twou'd be cowardly to fight in the Dark, and with a drunken Man—I'll call the Sentery.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: And expoſe us to the World?

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: I wou'd to Heav'n we were [Aſide]— [He comes forward.] Let me go, Madam, you pinch me to the Bone.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: He won't know us—I have my Maſque on.

sp.speaker: LADIES.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: What, is the Devil and his Imps playing at Blindman's Buff?—Ay, ay, here he is, indeed—Satan himſelf, dreſs'd like a fine Gentleman—Come, Mr. Devil, out with your Pitch-fork, and let us take a Thruſt or two.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: You miſtake me, Sir, I am not the Perſon— indeed, I am not—I know nothing of your Wife, Sir George—and if you know how little I care for the whole Sex, you wou'd not be ſo furious with an innocent Man.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Who are you then?—And what are you doing with that Blackamoor Lady there—dancing a Saraband with a Pair of Caſtanets? Speak, Sir!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p:
Pray forbear, Sir; here's Company coming that will ſatisfie you in every Thing—Hallo, hallo—
Here, here, here; [Hallo's faintly] my Lord, my my Lord—Spinner, Dizzy—Hallo!

div.stage: Enter Lord RACKET, Sir TAN-TIVY, SPINNER, and DIZZY, with Torches.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: What's the Matter here?—Who calls for Help?

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: [Running to 'em with his Sword drawn] O, my Friends, I have been wiſhing for you this half Hour. I have been ſet upon by a dozen Fellows—They have all made their Eſcape, but this—My Arm is quite dead—I have been at Cart and Tierce with 'em all, for near a Quarter of an Hour.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: In Buckram, my Lord!—He was got with my Property here, and I wou'd have chaſtis'd him for it, if your Coming had not prevented it.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Let us throw the Raſcal into Roſamond's Pond.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: Come Sir, can you ſwim?
sp.stage: [All going up. TUKELY ſnatches SOPHIA's Sword, and ſhe runs behind him.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: I'll defend you, my Dear—What, wou'd you murder a Man, and lie with his Wife too?—Oh! you are a wicked Gentleman, Mr. Daffodil.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Why, the Devil's in the Woman, I think.

sp.speaker: LADIES.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! your humble Servant, Mr. Daffodil— Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: This is all Enchantment!

sp.speaker: Lady PEWIT.
sp.p: No, Sir, the Enchantment is broke—and the old Maid, Sir, homely and wanton, before ſhe retires into the Country, has the Satisfaction of knowing that the agreeable Mr. Daffodil is a much more contemptible Mortal, than the Footman which his Goodneſs has been pleas'd to marry her to.

sp.speaker: LADIES.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Widow DAMPLY.
sp.p: Wou'd Mr. Daffodil pleaſe to have a Pinch of Spaniſh Snuff, out of the Great Mogul's Box? 'Tis the beſt Thing in the World for low Spirits.

sp.speaker: LADIES.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. DOTTEREL.
sp.p: If a Fool may not be permitted to ſpeak, Mr. Daffodil, let her at leaſt be permitted to laugh at ſo fine a Gentleman—Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: Were you as ſenſible of Shame, as you are of Fear, the Sight of me, whom you lov'd for Pity, wou'd be Revenge ſufficient—But I can forgive your Baſeneſs to me, much eaſier than I can myſelf, for my Behaviour to this happy Couple.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Who the Devil are they?

sp.speaker: ARABELLA.
sp.p: The Marquiſs and Marchioneſs of Macaroni, Ladies —Ha ha.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Ha! Mio Carriſſimo Amico, il Signior Daffodillo!

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: How! Tukely and Sophia!—If I don't wake ſoon, I ſhall wiſh never to wake again.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Who bids faireſt now for Roſamond's Pond?

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: What, in the Name of Wonder, is all this Buſineſs? I don't underſtand it.

sp.speaker: DIZZY.
sp.p: Nor I neither; but 'tis very drole, faith.

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: The Myſtery will clear in a Moment.

sp.speaker: DAFFODIL.
sp.p: Don't give yourſelf any Trouble, Mr. Tukely, Things are pretty clear as they are—The Night's cool, and my Couſin Dizzy, here, is an Invalid— If you pleaſe, another Time, when there is leſs Company, [Ladies laugh]— The Ladies are pleas'd to be merry, and you are pleas'd to be a little angry; and ſo, for the Sake of Tranquility—I'll go to the Opera.

sp.speaker: Lord RACKET.
sp.p: This is a fine blow-up, indeed! Ladies, your humble Servant—Hallo! Daffodil.

sp.speaker: DIZZY.
sp.p: I'll lay you a Hundred, that my Couſin never intrigues again—George! George! Don't run—hugh, hugh—

sp.speaker: TUKELY.
sp.p: As my Satisfaction is compleat, I have none to ask of Mr. Daffodil. I forgive his Behaviour to me, as it has haſten'd and confirm'd my Happineſs here; [to Sophia.]— But as a Friend to you, Ladies, I ſhall inſiſt upon his making you ample Satisfaction—However, this Benefit will ariſe, that you will hereafter equally deteſt and ſhun theſe Deſtroyers of your Reputation—
sp.l: In You Coquettry is a Loſs of Fame;
But in Our Sex, 'tis that deteſted Name,
That marks the Want of Manhood, Virtue, Senſe, and Shame.
